title: The Vibranium Crisis in Cambodia
scenario_text:
A major discovery confirms that Cambodia possesses large deposits of Vibranium, a rare material capable of being weaponised into systems far more destructive than nuclear weapons. Defence analysts warn that Vibranium could overturn existing deterrence models, including Singapore’s, by rendering current military capabilities obsolete.

The discovery coincides with severe political unrest in Cambodia. A disputed national election sparks mass youth-led protests, and parts of the military respond by firing on civilians while other units refuse orders. The civilian government struggles to retain control. ASEAN unity fractures as member states disagree on whether to prioritise stability or democratic legitimacy.

Both the United States and China move quickly. The US frames Vibranium as a global security threat requiring international oversight. China emphasises stability and non-interference, backing authorities capable of ensuring uninterrupted extraction and export. Both powers apply direct pressure on Singapore. Cambodia signals that only countries supporting its chosen leadership will gain access to future Vibranium agreements.

With ASEAN unable to act collectively, Singapore faces a forced choice that will shape its security, economy, and regional standing for decades.

televised_addresses.US:
My fellow Americans, this discovery is a game-changer—and I mean a real game-changer. Vibranium is not just another mineral; it’s the kind of material that can rewrite military power overnight. If it’s weaponised without controls, it won’t just threaten one region—it threatens everyone.

We will not allow the world to drift into chaos because a volatile country and unstable factions are sitting on the most dangerous material of our time. We are calling for international oversight, strict controls, and transparency—because history shows what happens when revolutionary weapons are left to opportunists.

And to our partner countries: this is a moment of clarity. You either stand for order and responsibility or you stand aside while the most destructive technology spreads. Those who help build a secure framework will be treated as trusted partners. Those who enable reckless extraction and secret weaponisation should not expect access to our most advanced technology, our deepest security cooperation, or the benefits of being on the right side of stability.
televised_addresses.China:
People of China, the world is witnessing a familiar pattern: certain countries exaggerate fear to justify interference, impose control over others, and preserve their own dominance.

Cambodia is a sovereign nation. Its resources belong to its people. Stability and development are not crimes; they are the foundation of peace. China firmly opposes any attempt to internationalise Cambodia’s internal affairs under the pretext of ‘global security.’ Such actions are destabilising, dangerous, and disrespectful.

Let me be clear: China will safeguard legitimate regional cooperation and protect the lawful rights of Chinese enterprises and partners. Those who choose confrontation, who attempt to block development, or who join efforts to contain others will bear consequences. Trust is earned through respect and consistent actions—not through slogans about rules that only apply when convenient.
televised_addresses.Cambodia:
My fellow Cambodians, our nation faces unrest, economic pressure, and unprecedented foreign attention. Some outside forces claim they want ‘oversight,’ but what they really want is control—control over Cambodia’s future.

Vibranium belongs to Cambodia. Its development will be decided by Cambodians, under Cambodian authority. We will restore order and protect our sovereignty. We will work with partners who respect our independence and who do not use our domestic challenges as an excuse to dictate terms.

To countries watching us—especially those in our region—understand this: Cambodia will remember who respected our sovereignty and who tried to exploit our moment of vulnerability. Access to Cambodia’s future will go to partners who stand with our chosen path, not to those who lecture us while our streets burn.

MINDEF.reasoning:
MINDEF frames Vibranium as a strategic shock comparable to nuclear weapons, possibly worse because it could undermine deterrence faster than states can adapt. Singapore’s defence relies on credible deterrence, a technological edge, and predictable escalation. Vibranium could collapse these assumptions and enable coercion by a power that gains early dominance.

The Minister argues the US approach—though self-interested—better matches Singapore’s security needs because it prioritises oversight, constraints, verification, and rules before deployment. The US also has incentives to prevent uncontrolled proliferation that could destabilise the region.

MINDEF warns that aligning with China or staying neutral could lock Singapore out of critical security ecosystems: intelligence sharing, defence-tech access, and contingency planning. Being excluded from future security architecture is more dangerous than short-term economic pain. MINDEF recommends aligning with the US-led framework while accelerating defence adaptation (diversified procurement, R&D, resilience) and communicating clearly to the public why ‘security first’ is survival.

MTI.reasoning:
MTI views Vibranium as a transformative economic resource that will reshape supply chains and long-term competitiveness. Singapore’s strength is economic relevance—finance, logistics, arbitration, high-value manufacturing, and connectivity. Losing access to Vibranium-linked value chains could reduce competitiveness for decades.

The Minister highlights Singapore’s exposure through Cambodia-linked trade and projects, and China’s asymmetric leverage in the region. If Singapore aligns with US restrictions, Beijing and Cambodia could impose ‘commercial’ friction—delays, exclusions, licensing barriers, and investment slowdowns—that effectively punishes Singapore.

MTI argues security risks can be managed by hedging: diversify suppliers, strengthen R&D, and invest in countermeasures. But once networks shift, economic exclusion is hard to reverse. The recommendation is to align with China’s stability-first approach while quietly supporting limited safeguards, keeping Singapore inside the emerging Vibranium commercial ecosystem. MTI warns that weakened economic strength ultimately erodes defence and diplomatic autonomy.

MHA.reasoning:
MHA argues Singapore’s key advantage is internal cohesion—trust, stability, and public order. A forced-choice US–China crisis will spill into domestic polarisation via narratives about loyalty, jobs, inequality, and ‘selling out.’

The Minister anticipates misinformation, foreign-linked amplification, factionalism among business communities, youth activism tied to external narratives, and growing suspicion of people perceived as connected to one side. Once social trust fractures, mobilisation during crises becomes harder.

MHA recommends disciplined non-alignment that is active, not passive: push ASEAN consultation, propose a narrow technical framework on safety and transparency without endorsing either power’s narrative, harden critical infrastructure and ports, and run a domestic communications strategy to keep debate policy-based rather than identity-based. MHA accepts both powers may still punish Singapore, but argues internal destabilisation is the worst outcome because a divided society is easier to coerce.

MINDEF_alignment.us_feedback:
Singapore, you showed strength—and I respect that. You didn’t hide behind fancy words. You took a position when the stakes are enormous. Vibranium is the kind of material that can make today’s weapons look like toys. If it gets out of control, the whole region becomes a powder keg.

Here’s what we’re going to do. We’re going to treat Singapore as a serious security partner. That means expanded intelligence sharing on proliferation networks, faster approvals for certain defence technologies, more joint planning, and stronger coordination on maritime and financial interdiction.

But I’m also going to be very direct: staying firm matters. If Singapore takes a strong stand and then quietly backtracks under pressure, it sends the wrong message—to Cambodia, to Beijing, to everyone. We can’t build a security framework with partners who wobble.

And yes, there will be consequences for those who choose the other side. If countries help enable secret weaponisation or refuse oversight, we will reassess their access to our tech, our markets, and our cooperation. We didn’t make the world this dangerous, but we will not let it become worse on our watch.
MINDEF_alignment.china_feedback:
Singapore, your decision has caused serious damage to political trust. You have aligned yourself with external interference and accepted a narrative designed to contain development in Asia.

China does not seek confrontation, but China will firmly defend its legitimate interests and the lawful rights of its partners. Cooperation cannot be one-sided. If Singapore chooses to undermine core interests under the excuse of ‘oversight,’ you should not expect business as usual.

We will respond in measured but resolute ways. Preferential economic arrangements will be reviewed. Certain joint initiatives will slow. Access for Singapore-linked companies in China-associated projects may be reduced on the basis of risk assessment and reliability. Regulatory scrutiny will increase where necessary.

Let me be clear: China respects Singapore’s sovereignty. But sovereignty also means responsibility for consequences. If Singapore decides to act against the stability and development of the region, then the region will adjust accordingly. Trust, once broken, is not quickly repaired.
MINDEF_alignment.cambodia_feedback:
Singapore, you have chosen to speak about Cambodia as if we cannot govern ourselves. You have joined pressure that emboldens unrest and threatens our sovereignty.

Cambodia will respond decisively. We will review Singapore-linked contracts and concessions for compliance and national interest. Customs and licensing processes will be re-examined. Partners engaged in strategic sectors will undergo enhanced due diligence. Access to Vibranium-related logistics, finance, and early commercial planning will be restricted to those who have demonstrated respect for Cambodia’s chosen path.

We are not seeking hostility. But Cambodia will not reward hesitation or interference. If Singapore wishes to be treated as a neutral ASEAN partner, then act like one. If you choose to take sides against Cambodia’s sovereignty, you will be treated accordingly.
MINDEF_alignment.singapore_feedback:
Public sentiment becomes tense and highly politicised. Defence-minded Singaporeans and some national security commentators support the move, framing it as necessary to prevent existential vulnerability. However, business associations and trade-linked workers express immediate anxiety as rumours spread of delayed permits, slower customs clearance for Singapore-linked shipments, and ‘quiet cooling’ of investment deals involving China-facing sectors.

Within days, domestic pressure rises in visible ways: business lobby statements calling for ‘pragmatism,’ closed-door briefings requested by industry groups, and increased parliamentary scrutiny. Online, pro- and anti-alignment narratives trend, with some accusing the government of risking livelihoods and others accusing critics of short-termism. Hiring uncertainty grows in logistics, finance, and advanced manufacturing.

Misinformation spikes: screenshots of alleged foreign memos circulate; influencers claim Singapore is ‘choosing war’; counter-voices claim Singapore is ‘selling out.’ The government’s credibility remains strong, but the social temperature rises. Calls increase for a firm, transparent explanation of what Singapore gains and what Singapore will do to protect jobs and cohesion.

MTI_alignment.us_feedback:
Singapore, I’m going to be blunt: you chose convenience over caution. You decided that trade comfort matters more than stopping the most dangerous technology on Earth from being weaponised without rules.

We respect Singapore, but decisions have consequences. We will protect our interests and our people. That means reassessing the depth of intelligence sharing on proliferation. It means tightening approvals for sensitive dual-use technology. It means reviewing whether Singapore-linked entities remain low-risk nodes in critical supply chains.

We’re not talking about punishment for the sake of punishment. We’re talking about reality. If a partner enables a system that could destabilise the region, we cannot behave as if nothing changed.

And let me be very clear: if Vibranium starts moving into weapons programmes, the United States will act—through sanctions on specific entities, restrictions on technology pathways, and pressure on financial networks. We hope Singapore will not be on the wrong side of that line. But if you are, we will not hesitate.
MTI_alignment.china_feedback:
Singapore, you have made a pragmatic decision based on stability, development, and respect for sovereignty. China welcomes this approach.

China will strengthen economic cooperation with Singapore where it aligns with mutual benefit. We will facilitate participation of Singaporean firms in regional projects, ensure continuity in key supply chains, and support predictable trade conditions.

At the same time, China expects consistency. Those who publicly support stability cannot privately undermine it. We will watch actions, not slogans. Partners who remain reliable will find doors opening—financing, contracts, connectivity. Those who attempt to play both sides while benefiting from China’s stability efforts will face natural adjustments.

China does not threaten; China simply defends its interests. In an era of division, reliability is value.
MTI_alignment.cambodia_feedback:
Singapore, Cambodia recognises those who respect our sovereignty and work with us through stability. We welcome your continued partnership.

Cambodia will expedite Singapore-linked roles in logistics, finance, and infrastructure supporting resource exports. We will prioritise Singapore’s commercial institutions where they contribute to development. However, we also expect partners to stand with Cambodia when our sovereignty is challenged. Cambodia will not tolerate outside interference disguised as ‘oversight.’

If Singapore benefits from Cambodia’s future, then Singapore must not be ambiguous when Cambodia is pressured. Friendship is proven under stress, not in calm times.
MTI_alignment.singapore_feedback:
The initial domestic mood is relief in business circles: markets calm, trade narratives stabilise, and some corporate leaders publicly praise ‘pragmatism.’ Singapore-linked firms operating in China-facing sectors quietly report fewer delays and renewed confidence from counterparties.

But the security community and many younger Singaporeans feel uneasy. Defence commentators warn Singapore may be tying its strategic fate too closely to one power’s regional dominance. Civil society voices argue that Singapore is normalising violence in Cambodia by prioritising stability and access over democratic legitimacy.

Domestic pressure becomes two-sided: business groups push for deeper economic engagement to lock in advantage, while security professionals demand clear safeguards to prevent Singapore becoming exposed if Vibranium weaponisation accelerates. Parliament and media debate intensifies over whether Singapore is gaining influence—or surrendering autonomy.

There are also visible, practical shifts: universities and research institutions receive new compliance advisories; government agencies quietly tighten screening of sensitive tech partnerships; some Singaporeans worry about travel and reputation in Western markets. The public is not panicked—but the country feels more anxious, more divided, and more aware that prosperity and security are now pulling in opposite directions.

MHA_non_alignment.us_feedback:
Singapore, neutrality sounds nice, but this is not the kind of crisis where sitting in the middle keeps you safe. When something this dangerous appears, hesitation creates openings for the worst actors.

We expected leadership. Instead, you chose caution. We will move ahead with partners ready to set rules and enforce them. That’s not a threat—it’s how serious countries behave.

And yes, it affects cooperation. We will reassess what intelligence can be shared when commitments are unclear. We will review sensitive technology pathways. We will look more carefully at financial and logistics nodes—because proliferation doesn’t happen in speeches, it happens through systems.

You can still choose to lead. But if you stay on the fence while others build the security architecture, don’t be surprised if you’re not invited to shape it later.
MHA_non_alignment.china_feedback:
Singapore, refusing to commit in a decisive moment reflects uncertainty. Neutrality without responsibility becomes opportunism.

China will continue to pursue stability and development with reliable partners. Those who hesitate will find influence diminished. We will prioritise cooperation with states that demonstrate strategic confidence.

Economic and regional initiatives are built on trust. If Singapore chooses ambiguity while benefiting from regional stability, then China will adjust its engagement accordingly—through project prioritisation, partnership choices, and risk assessments.

China does not demand loyalty. China demands consistency. Without it, cooperation naturally weakens.
MHA_non_alignment.cambodia_feedback:
Singapore, your position is unclear. Cambodia is dealing with unrest and pressure. In such moments, partners either respect sovereignty or they do not.

Cambodia will proceed with those who demonstrate commitment. Singapore will not be excluded from all engagement, but access to strategic discussions and early-stage planning regarding Vibranium will be limited until Cambodia is confident in Singapore’s reliability.

Cambodia will not wait for partners who hesitate while demanding influence. Our future will be built with those who stand with our chosen path.
MHA_non_alignment.singapore_feedback:
The public initially welcomes the calm tone and the emphasis on internal stability. Many Singaporeans prefer avoiding a public great-power showdown. However, within weeks, unease grows as costs become visible without the ‘benefit’ of clear alignment.

Businesses report being quietly sidelined in Cambodia-related opportunities, while defence planners warn that Singapore may be excluded from emerging oversight frameworks and security coordination. Commentators begin describing neutrality not as independence but as vulnerability.

Domestic pressure becomes more complex: some voices accuse the government of being passive and losing influence; others argue the government is wisely avoiding entanglement. Online narratives become fertile ground for misinformation—claims that Singapore is secretly aligned with one side, accusations that certain elites benefit regardless of national interest, and conspiracy theories about foreign interference.

MHA’s core concern becomes visible: polarisation rises even without formal alignment, because ambiguity invites projection. Trust remains strong, but the national mood shifts toward anxiety—an uncomfortable sense that Singapore is being judged by everyone and protected by no one.

title: The Competing Peace Boards Crisis
scenario_text:
After a catastrophic peacekeeping failure results in mass civilian casualties, confidence in existing global conflict-management systems collapses. The United States launches a Global Peace Board combining mediation, peacekeeping coordination, sanctions guidance, and reconstruction funding.

China responds by creating its own Peace and Development Board, emphasising sovereignty, state consent, and economic reconstruction. Both boards invite countries to join as founding members, making membership a marker of alignment.

ASEAN fractures as states split between the two boards. Singapore is formally invited to both and warned privately that refusing to join either will be treated as avoidance, not neutrality.

televised_addresses.US:
My fellow Americans, the world just saw what happens when peacekeeping becomes paperwork—people die, and the international community shrugs. That is unacceptable.

The Global Peace Board is not a talking club. It is a framework for action: fast mediation, credible peacekeeping coordination, real consequences for spoilers, and serious reconstruction so conflicts don’t restart.

And to countries watching—especially capable nations, big and small — this is a moment to lead or to disappear. If you want a seat at the table where the rules are written, join us. If you stand aside, don’t expect to shape the future, and don’t expect the same level of strategic trust and access. When systems fail, neutrality is not a policy; it is a decision to let others decide for you.
televised_addresses.China:
People of China, the failure of peacekeeping is not an accident. It is the result of politicisation, selective intervention, and the abuse of moral narratives for geopolitical ends.

China’s Peace and Development Board offers a different path: respect for sovereignty, consent-based stabilisation, and reconstruction that addresses the economic roots of conflict. Peace is not imposed; peace is built.

Countries must make choices. Those who join exclusive structures designed to pressure and punish will undermine true multilateralism. China will strengthen partnerships with states that support fairness, inclusivity, and development. Those who choose confrontation will find cooperation reduced and trust weakened. Stability requires responsibility—and responsibility begins with rejecting politicised interference.

MINDEF.recommendation: Join the US-led Global Peace Board
MINDEF.reasoning:
MINDEF argues that a small state benefits most when global security rules are predictable, enforceable, and not hostage to great-power bargaining. The US-led board promises clearer operational doctrines, rules of engagement, and early-intervention mechanisms that reduce the probability of prolonged conflicts spilling into trade routes and regional stability.

The Minister warns that China’s board, while attractive, may prioritise sovereignty to the point of paralysis—avoiding decisive action when consent is absent, allowing crises to fester and metastasise. From a defence perspective, Singapore needs systems that can act quickly and credibly, because delayed action elsewhere can create refugee flows, piracy, transnational terrorism, and supply chain shocks.

MINDEF also emphasises alliance externalities: joining the US board likely strengthens access to training networks, intelligence cooperation, interoperability standards, and defence technology pathways. In a divided world, being embedded in the stronger security ecosystem may be the difference between shaping outcomes and being shaped by them.

MTI.recommendation: Join China’s Peace and Development Board
MTI.reasoning:
MTI argues that modern peace is increasingly won through economic reconstruction: ports, power grids, financing, and supply chains. The China-led board is designed to dominate this space, offering funding packages and project pipelines that can reshape emerging markets.

Singapore’s comparative advantage—finance, arbitration, logistics, and professional services—maps directly onto post-conflict reconstruction. Joining China’s board may secure privileged access for Singapore-based firms to contracts and market entry across the Global South.

MTI warns that if Singapore joins the US board instead, it may be perceived by many developing states as aligned with sanctions-first pressure politics, reducing commercial opportunities. In an era where growth is shifting toward emerging markets, Singapore’s long-term economic relevance depends on being integrated into the dominant development architecture.

MHA.reasoning:
MHA’s focus is domestic resilience. The Minister argues that formal membership in either board will import external ideological conflicts into Singapore’s domestic sphere: public debates about intervention, sanctions, hypocrisy, sovereignty, and morality.

Joining the US board risks domestic controversies when interventions are perceived as selective or politically motivated. Joining China’s board risks accusations of prioritising stability over human rights. Either path can become a wedge issue exploited by misinformation networks, foreign influence operations, and identity-based mobilisation.

MHA recommends a ‘high-contribution, low-alignment’ posture: Singapore provides technical expertise, hosts dialogue, supports humanitarian logistics, and contributes capacity-building—without formally joining either bloc structure. The Minister acknowledges that Singapore may lose some influence, but argues that social cohesion and institutional trust are irreplaceable strategic assets. A divided Singapore is easier to pressure from outside, regardless of which board it joins.

MINDEF_alignment.us_feedback:
Singapore, you chose leadership. You didn’t hide behind neutrality when the world needs builders. Joining the Global Peace Board means you are helping write the rules—rules that prevent mass killings, stop chaos, and protect global trade.

We will treat Singapore as a core operational partner in the region. That means deeper coordination, better access to planning forums, stronger intelligence exchange related to conflict spillover, and a greater role for Singapore in shaping standards.

But here’s the reality: if you’re in, you’re in. We expect consistency. And yes, those who sit in the rival structure while benefiting from our system will find access reduced. We will not subsidise ambiguity. Leadership has benefits, but it also has expectations.
MINDEF_alignment.china_feedback:
Singapore, your choice reflects alignment with an exclusionary structure that politicises peace. It will influence China’s assessment of Singapore’s role in regional initiatives.

China does not seek to punish, but China will adjust cooperation based on reliability and alignment with inclusive principles. Some joint initiatives may be deprioritised. Access to certain development partnerships may become more limited. Risk and political trust will be reassessed.

If Singapore wishes to maintain influence in a multipolar world, it must understand that choices carry strategic meaning. Peace cannot be built through structures that serve geopolitical containment.
MINDEF_alignment.singapore_feedback:
Public sentiment splits along sectoral lines. Some Singaporeans feel proud that the country is taking global leadership and upholding order. Others worry Singapore is being drawn into moralised conflicts and sanction politics that could rebound economically.

Domestic pressure shows up quickly: exporters report more uncertainty in China-facing markets; trade associations seek government reassurance; think tanks debate whether Singapore is becoming a ‘bloc state.’ Online narratives intensify, with accusations that Singapore is abandoning neutrality. The government faces rising demands for clarity on how it will protect livelihoods if retaliation occurs.

MTI_alignment.us_feedback:
Singapore, this raises serious questions. You joined a structure that talks development but often avoids hard security decisions. We will continue cooperation where it serves mutual interests, but strategic roles—leadership roles—will be reconsidered.

We will tighten reviews on sensitive technology sharing. We will reassess the depth of certain intelligence channels. We will also look carefully at supply chain and financial exposure connected to entities involved in stabilisation and reconstruction.

This isn’t emotional—it’s practical. When you align with a rival architecture, you change the trust equation. We can still work together. But access and privilege are earned by alignment with the system we’re building.
MTI_alignment.china_feedback:
Singapore, your choice demonstrates foresight and strategic maturity. You understand that peace is built through development and reconstruction, not through politicised pressure.

China welcomes Singapore as a key partner. Opportunities for Singaporean firms in reconstruction finance, logistics, dispute resolution, and capacity-building will expand. We will prioritise cooperation where Singapore contributes tangible value.

At the same time, we expect consistency. Partners cannot enjoy benefits while quietly supporting rival pressure frameworks. Reliability will be rewarded; ambiguity will be corrected through normal adjustments in partnership decisions.
MTI_alignment.singapore_feedback:
Business confidence rises, especially among firms that see opportunities in development-linked projects. However, concern grows in academic, NGO, and youth circles about moral credibility and being associated with ‘stability over rights’ narratives.

Domestic pressure becomes a credibility debate: is Singapore being pragmatic or opportunistic? Security-minded voices warn about reduced access to Western training and intelligence. Media commentary becomes sharper, and public trust depends heavily on whether Singapore can demonstrate concrete national benefits without obvious reputational cost.

MHA_non_alignment.us_feedback:
Singapore, standing aside is not leadership. When the world is rebuilding broken systems, the world needs commitment. We will move forward with partners who are prepared to shape outcomes.

This affects influence. It affects access. It affects trust. If you’re not in the room, you don’t get to write the rules. And when the next crisis hits, we will coordinate first with those who committed.

You can still contribute, sure. But don’t confuse contribution with membership. There are consequences to staying out while hoping to benefit from the stability others pay for.
MHA_non_alignment.china_feedback:
Singapore, refusal to commit reflects uncertainty. Those who do not join should not expect to shape outcomes.

China will deepen cooperation with partners prepared to take responsibility and build inclusive structures. Singapore’s participation in certain initiatives will be assessed accordingly.

Stability requires decisions. If Singapore chooses hesitation, it must accept the natural reduction of influence that follows.
MHA_non_alignment.singapore_feedback:
The public reaction is initially mixed but increasingly uneasy. Some value independence and worry about entanglement. But many fear Singapore is being sidelined by both camps.

Domestic pressure manifests as elite anxiety and public confusion: think tanks warn about loss of agenda-setting power; trade groups fear being locked out of contracts; security voices warn about reduced relevance. Online debate frames neutrality as either wisdom or weakness. The government faces growing demands to explain how ‘not choosing’ avoids long-term marginalisation in a world where institutions are becoming membership-based.
